data.text: Contents
Introduction

This document describes how adult general critical care services across Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust will respond to sustained increases in demand as a consequence of winter pressures, pandemic events and other major incidents.

Adult general critical care is delivered by the general critical care units at Basildon Hospital (CCU and Frederick Banting), Broomfield Hospital (GICU and GHDU) and Southend Hospital (CCU and Kitty Hubbard Unit). It does not include the specially commissioned services of the burns intensive care unit (BICU) at Broomfield Hospital or the cardiothoracic intensive care unit (Colne Ward) at the Essex Cardiothoracic Centre.
This plan will be subject to frequent change and as a minimum will be reviewed every six months.

Critical care capacity may differ from the commissioned establishment due to operational pressures such as staff vacancy or sickness, estates issues or equipment failure and this plan must be read in conjunction with any capacity alerts escalated by the critical care senior leadership.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

To maintain the safe delivery of adult general critical care to the population of Mid & South Essex without recourse to resource-limited decision making, in-line with existing legal and ethical best practice.
To protect patients and staff from infection with established, new or emerging respiratory viruses, including Covid-19.

To maximise relative to the capacity available, the Trust's capability to safely provide cancer, cardiac and urgent elective care by prospectively identifying how such services can be protected through alternative care pathways.

To protect and support healthcare workers by prospectively providing clear guidance as to how teams will be supported and to reduce the cognitive burden associated with decision making in uncertain circumstances.

To support colleagues in senior management and operational positions by providing clear clinical justification for decisions made during surge events and by defining the expected organisational response during such times.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
The MSE Critical Care Governance Board will be responsible for review and approval of this surge plan.

The MSE Clinical Director for Critical Care or Head of Nursing (or nominated deputies) will be responsible for designation of the Trust's CRITCON status and as such for determining escalation of the Trust's surge response.
The Deputy Director or Director of Operations for Care Group 1, Division 2 will be responsible for co-ordination of the operational and executive responsibilities as outlined in the CRITCON matrix.
At CRITCON 2 or higher, the Chief Operating Officer (or nominated deputy) will be responsible for escalating awareness of surge incidents to regional partners.
Critical Care Capacity
Understanding capacity

5.1.1 Critical care capacity is most frequently determined by the number of intensive care nurses available to care for patients. Safe staffing ratios are clearly defined in national guidance and this varies depending on the level of care required by the patient case mix. Consequently the maximum number of patients that can be accommodated within critical care (capacity) can vary.

5.1.2 Critical care capacity can also be described in terms of the maximum number of physical bed spaces available to receive patients, though it is more common that capacity is staffing-constrained than space-constrained.

Capacity management

5.3.1 Critical care capacity when described as occupancy or bed numbers can be difficult to interpret and does not always reflect real-world pressure within the system. CRITCON level designation will be used to determine the actions required to meet surge pressures.

5.3.2 The CRITCON level will be reported for MSENFT general critical care as a whole, not on the basis of individual sites. Authority for CRITCON designation lays with the MSENFT Clinical Director for Critical Care or MSENFT Critical Care Head or Nursing (or nominated deputies).

data.text: Escalation plan for CRITCON 0 and CRITCON 1
The escalation response to sudden capacity breaches at individual site level will be as follows:
The on-call ICU consultant and nurse in charge (NIC) will review patients for stepdown to create capacity. Step-downs will be escalated to the local site

management team. In the event that this occurs out of hours, the consultant and NIC may make a risk assessment and choose to defer the stepdown until normal working hours and admit the emergency patient, temporarily breaking GPICS/ UKCCNA staffing ratios.
The on-call ICU consultant and NIC can review patients to decide on how best to

cohort patients and staff to see if additional capacity can be created. Out of hours a risk assessment that considers the skill mix of available staffing and patient casemix may be undertaken and the emergency patient admitted, temporarily breaking GPICS/ UKCCNA staffing ratios.
Out of hours, critical care admissions to the theatre recovery area should be

used preferentially to make the site safe. The decision as to which patient is most appropriate to transfer to recovery is determined by the critical care consultant on-call in partnership with the theatre recovery team. When a patient is admitted to a recovery area, the patient remains the responsibility of the critical care consultant on-call, unless otherwise agreed. Direct care should primarily be delivered by the on-call anaesthetic team with support from the critical care junior doctor team.
If staffing ratios are broken overnight or a patient(s) is admitted to a non-critical

care area under the critical care team, it is the responsibility of the incoming critical consultant to re-assess critical care capacity and arrange for non-clinical transfer within MSENFT to restore safe staffing ratios and emergency critical care capacity.
During normal working hours it is the responsibility of the critical consultant on- call to arrange for non-clinical transfer to restore safe staffing ratios and emergency critical care capacity.

When there is no capacity for transfer within MSENFT, this should be escalated to the MSENFT CD for Critical Care or Head of Nursing (or nominated deputies). This situation will trigger an upgrade to CRITCON 2 and this will be reported into Gold Command.
At this stage non-clinical transfer within the EoECCODN is necessary and is the responsibility of the on-call critical care consultant to arrange.
Nursing staffing

6.2.1  GPICS/ UKCCNA compliant staff ratios must be maintained until CRITCON 2 is declared, though the phased draw down of B nurses should be considered in CRITCON 1 to prepare for further escalation.
Medical staffing
6.3.1 GPICS/ ICS compliant staff ratios must be maintained until CRITCON 2 is declared and should be met within usual consultant job plans and junior doctor staffing levels.
6.3.2 Support will be required from anaesthesia on an ad hoc basis to provide medical escort for increasing amounts of transfer work.

Medical staffing

7.3.1 CRITCON 2 level activity will put considerable strain on critical care consultant: patient ratios on all sites. Critical care consultant: patient ratio cannot exceed 1:12 at any time outside of CRITCON 3.

7.3.2 AT CRITCON 2 redeployment of consultants with transferable skills to critical care should be commenced with the intention of providing 1 consultant to each site between 08:00 and 20:00. Redeployed consultants can provide direct care on critical care (supporting the junior doctor team and troubleshooting) or take on responsibilities (such as outreach, liaison with ARCU teams, review of referrals) to relieve critical care consultant pressure and allow them to primarily focus on senior decision-making work.

7.3.3 CRITCON 2 level activity require redeployment of junior doctors to critical care to preserve safe staffing ratios, which must be maintained 24 hours a day. Critical care junior doctor: patient ratios must not exceed 1:8 at any time outside of CRITCON 3.

7.3.4 CRITCON 2 level activity will inevitably mean that each site is caring for level 3 (V) patients in at least two geographically separate sites and as such it is redeployment of doctors with advanced airway skills (anaesthetists) that will be necessary.

7.3.5 For every  critical care beds, there must be at least one junior doctor with advanced airways skills capable of independently performing a rapid sequence intubation in a critically ill patient. The definition of such a doctor would be a trainee in a nationally approved training programme in intensive care medicine or anaesthesia at ST3+ level or a non-training grade doctor with skills equivalent to the RCoA Initial Assessment of Competence and at least 12 months experience in critical care or anaesthesia at a level equivalent to ST3+.

7.3.6 When this skill mix cannot be maintained, additional support by anaesthetic consultant redeployment will be necessary. This can be through local agreement where MERIT teams are created to support critical care and removal of critical care teams from first responder roles in MET, cardiac arrest and trauma calls.

Special arrangements relating to Covid-19
Critical Care Capacity
9.1.1 Admission of Covid-19 patients to critical care will have the impact of reducing overall critical care capacity.
9.1.2 Each of the core adult general critical care units will maintain a geographically separate space for the care of patients with confirmed or strongly suspected Covid-19.

9.1.3 To preserve level 3 capacity, patients with Covid-19 requiring non-invasive respiratory support (high flow oxygen, high-flow nasal cannulae or CPAP/ NIV) should be managed through ARCU where possible provided that there are clear plans for escalation and critical care review.
9.1.4 There should be scheduled twice daily consultant discussion of ARCU patients of concern between critical care and respiratory medicine.
9.1.5 The designated areas for this at site level are:

data.text: 9.1.6 Mid-Essex and Southend sites should be kept within “area 2” for as long as possible by non-clinical transfer between sites, even if this pushes Basildon into area 3. This is to preserve non-Covid emergency capacity on these sites and to preserve surgical capacity at the major MSENFT cancer centres for as long as possible. The aim at Basildon is to prevent surge into CTC Colne Ward to preserve cancer and cardiac surgical capabilities.

9.1.7 Basildon site should be kept within its retained capacity of 6 non-Covid-19 beds for as long as possible by non-clinical transfer between sites. This is to preserve capacity to decompress Covid-19 from the other sites and to prevent encroachment into CTC Colne Ward.

Staff sickness and reporting arrangements
9.4.1 Staff sickness in critical care will continued to be reported in line with existing local reporting procedures.
9.4.2 Additional sickness reporting procedures may arise as a result of central MSENFT sickness reporting policy changes.
Visiting

9.5.1 National guidance takes primacy over local policy on visiting. Secondary to this, visiting arrangements are then determined by the site critical care leadership team as they see most appropriate in the circumstances.

9.5.2 During surge events the critical care consultant on-call and NIC may make the decision to suspend all visiting so that resources can be maximally diverted to patient care. In such an event non-clinical staff should be used to inform patient's visitors of these emergency restrictions.

9.5.3 In sustained surge where visiting is suspended for greater than 24hours, the site teams should consider implementing a scheduled daily telephone call to a patient's next of kin or nominated advocate in order to maintain clear communication. A patient “password” system should be used to maintain confidentiality.
9.5.4 Visiting access should still be considered on day 1 for newly admitted patients and if there is a sudden, serious deterioration or the patient is placed on an end of life pathway.
Co-ordination of the MSENFT response
The MSENFT critical care senior leadership will constantly monitor the CRITCON status. This will determine trigger actions for increasing escalation to operations within and across the care group(s).
If CRITCON 1 is declared, this will trigger the 9am virtual cross-site senior ICU leadership meeting (“huddle”) on Monday, Wednesday and Friday.
If CRITCON 2 is declared, the huddle will stand up to all weekdays with sit rep procedure continuing at weekends supported by an on-call senior nursing and senior medical leader – see appendix 1.
If CRITCON 3 is declared, the huddle will stand up to 7 days a week.

The critical care huddle will be held at 9am using MS Teams. The purpose of this meeting is to identify the total system load, identify particular hot spots and co-ordinate a plan for decompression as necessary.
The operating policy for the critical care huddle is embedded as an appendix within this plan.
Inter-hospital transfer
Non-clinical transfers to decompress hot sites should be planned 24 hours in advance wherever possible.
There must always be both a verbal consultant- consultant handover and a nurse- nurse handover of the patient prior to transfer.
At CRITCON 0 and 1 the expectation is that the medical cover for a critical care transfer is provided by the anaesthetic department from the sending site, arranged on an ad hoc basis.

At CRITCON 2 and 3 the expectation is that medical cover for a critical care transfer will be provided by redeployment of anaesthetic consultants from across the three MSENFT core sites, contributing to a roster to share the burden fairly.
Transfers will be planned and agreed at the 9am critical care huddle at CRITCON >1. Only the chair of the huddle can authorise a transfer.

Emergency non-clinical transfers for decompression may be required outside of the scope of the 9am huddle. In this instance the chair of the 9am huddle for that day can be contacted to signpost the sending unit as to where capacity is available. It is then the responsibility of the sending unit to contact the receiving unit to agree transfer and to make arrangements for transfer.
Equipment

MSENFT have sufficient retained equipment to surge to 60 level 3 (V) beds with capacity to provide level 2 care (O+) for greater than that number. An inventory of available equipment is held on the MSB Critical Care Drive.

The co-ordination of equipment will be managed cross site by the leads for MSENFT Critical Care Technology Services (Critical Care Technology at Basildon and Broomfield and Specialist Medical Equipment Technician, MEMS at Southend).

In the event that additional equipment is required, this should be escalated to the MSENFT CD for Critical Care or Head of Nursing (or nominated deputies) to arrange relief from the EoECCODN regional equipment programme.
Infection Control & Cohorting

Good infection and control prevention practices are vital to protect patients and staff. The same standard of infection prevention and control is expected in critical care expansion areas as is expected within critical care.

It is likely that the requirement to isolate patients with infectious/communicable diseases will outstrip facilities to do so in pandemic events. In these situations the critical care consultant and NIC (at a site level) should look to cohort patients pragmatically and the following scheme is recommended:
Training Requirements
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and Audit
The effectiveness of the policy will be discussed annually at the Critical Care Governance Board and will be evaluated following surge events through After Action Review.
Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Critical Care Governance Board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve Trust critical care guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the members of the MSE Critical Care Governance Board of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
